title: Restaurant Review: Kabawa in the East Village
description: Our critic reviews Kabawa in the East Village, where Paul Carmichael brings a singular skill (but no fussiness) to the food he grew up on.
author: Ligaya Mishan
excerpt: Our critic reviews Kabawa in the East Village, where Paul Carmichael brings a singular skill (but no fussiness) to the food he grew up on.

html:
You have a preview view of this article while we are checking your access. When we have confirmed access, the full article content will load.

The Caribbean, Filtered Through One Chef’s Imagination

Our critic reviews Kabawa in the East Village, where Paul Carmichael brings a singular skill (but no fussiness) to the food he grew up on.

Credit...Video by Yuvraj Khanna For The New York Times

  • July 8, 2025Updated 10:24 a.m. ET
Kabawa
NYT Critic’s Pick
★★★
Caribbean
$$$
8 Extra Place, East Village
646-790-8747

The tamarind pod is dusky brown, light and rough to the touch. Press it with your thumbs or give it a twist. When it cracks, peel off the shell, pull out the veins and free the pulp — sticky as figs and more sweet than sour, because the fruit’s so ripe. Still you’ll pucker a little, working your tongue around the seeds.

Presented at Kabawa before dessert, this might be the loveliest palate cleanser in town. It’s all the lovelier for being a little messy, in keeping with the restaurant’s ethos: fine dining, but without the pomp.

Kabawa opened in late March in the space once home to the half-bonkers, half-sublime Momofuku Ko, on a dead-end alley off East First Street named, as if with a shrug, Extra Place. In 1977, the address was sufficiently down-and-out to be the backdrop for a Ramones album cover; if you sneaked out the back of the punk club CBGB, this was where you wound up.

The chef, Paul Carmichael, grew up in Barbados and worked his way through New York City kitchens before taking the lead at Momofuku Seiobo in Sydney, Australia, the farthest-flung outpost of the Momofuku empire. It closed in 2021 — luckily for New Yorkers, for now Momofuku has brought Mr. Carmichael’s superlative cooking and ambitious vision of Caribbean cuisine back to us.
